questions.text: A 30 yrs old male came to the casualty complaining of passing orange urine. He was started on antituberculosis drugs for pulmonary tuberculosis. Which drug is responsible for the above urine finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rifampicin Patients should be advised that rifampin typically causes an orange or red-orange discoloration of body fluids (including urine, sweat, saliva, and tears).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Doxycycline: it does not cause orange color urine. Option: C. streptomycin: it does not cause orange color urine.

Extraedge:

Brown/Black (Tea-colored) : Bile pigments, cascara, chloroquine, fava beans, levodopa, melanin or oxidized melanogenic, methemoglobin, methyldopa, metronidazole, myoglobin, nitrofurantoin , primaquine, rhubarb, riboflavin, senna Dark Yellow : Concentrated specimen (dehydration, exercise) Green/Blue: Triamterene , Amitriptyline, asparagus, biliverdin, cimetidine, closets (breath mint), indicans, indigo carmine, indomethacin, methocarbamol, methylene blue, promethazine, propofol, pseudomonal UTI, triamterene Orange: Bile pigments, carrots, coumadin, phenothiazines, phenazopyridine, rifampin , vitamin C Pink/Red : Beets, blackberries, chlorpromazine, food dyes, hematuria, hemoglobinuria, menstrual contamination, myoglobinuria, phenolphthalein, porphyrins, rifampin, rhubarb, senna, thioridazine, uric acid crystals. A urine sample that turns red on standing suggests the presence of porphobilinogen, which is increased in acute porphyrias. Option B. Rifampicin: it is the antituberculosis drug that causes orange urine. So, it may look like hematuria.

questions.text: A 30 year old male came to the casualty with a complaint of urine turning red while standing for 10 min. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Porphyrias A urine sample that turns red on standing suggests the presence of porphobilinogen, which is increased in acute porphyrias. Option B. porphyrias: In porphyria, the urine turns red on standing due to presence of pigment porphobilinogen.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. urinary stones:it leads to hematuria ,leading to red urine which don’t change with time. Option: C. hemoglobinuria leads to brown or red urine ,leading to red urine which doesn't change with time.

Extraedge:

Second Urine of the morning is preferred to the first urine sample because prolonged standing of urine in the bladder favors the lysis of urine cells and practicals. Analysis should be done within 2-4 hours Storage 2-8 degrees for a maximum of 12 hours

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with diabetes complains of a very putrid odor of urine and pain in the abdomen with fever episodes. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinary tract infection Cystine Decomposition: Sulfuric smell Dehydration/Prolonged Room Temperature: Strong smell Diabetic Ketoacidosis: Fruity/sweet Gastrointestinal-bladder Fistula: Fecal smell Urinary Tract Infection: Pungent or fetid Urinary tract infection: The pt is diabetic with putrid urine with fever suggestive of urinary tract infection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. urinary stones: It will lead to hematuria and pain in the abdomen. Option: C. glomerulonephritis: It will lead to hematuria and pain in the abdomen. It is usually associated with dysmorphic hematuria.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the casualty with a complaint of passing brown urine, he was later diagnosed having myoglobinuria. What are the causes for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above URINE ANALYSIS: Blood Cells Dipstick test for blood detects primarily the peroxidase activity of erythrocytes , but myoglobin and hemoglobin can also catalyze this reaction. Thus, a positive test result indicates hematuria, myoglobinuria, or hemoglobinuria. Normal: Negative (usually) or less than or equal to 5 RBCs per mL (lab-dependent value) Associations Hematuria: Renal ca:lculi, glomerulonephritis, pyelonephritis, tumors, trauma, anticoagulants, strenuous exercise, exposure to toxic chemicals. Glomerulonephritis is associated with dysmorphic hematuria whereas tubular disorders are associated with isomorphic hematuria. Hemoglobinuria : Hemolytic anemias, RBC trauma, strenuous exercise, transfusion reactions, severe burns, infections (i.e., malaria) Myoglobinuria : Muscle trauma eg, rhabdomyolysis, prolonged coma, convulsions, drug abuse, extensive exertion, alcoholism/overdose, muscle wasting diseases. Option A. rhabdomyolysis: It can lead to muscle trauma which can lead to myoglobinuria. Option B. Convulsions: It can lead to muscle trauma which can lead to myoglobinuria. Option C. Extensive exertion: It can lead to muscle trauma which can lead to myoglobinuria.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male complained of passing red urine, later the diagnosis was confirmed as hemoglobinuria. Which of the following can be the cause responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above URINALYSIS: Blood Cells Dipstick test for blood detects primarily the peroxidase activity of erythrocytes , but myoglobin and hemoglobin can also catalyze this reaction. Thus, a positive test result indicates hematuria, myoglobinuria , or hemoglobinuria . Option: A. Hemolytic anemias: In this condition, there is lysis of red blood cells leading to hemoglobinuria. Option: B. transfusion reactions: In this condition, there is a lysis of red blood cells leading to hemoglobinuria Option: C. infections: In this condition, there is a lysis of red blood cells leading to hemoglobinuria.

questions.text: A 60 years old male with a known case of diabetes is suffering from pain in his abdomen and a fever. His urine nitrite test is positive. Which of the following is responsible for this positive test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Nitrites : Products originating from the reduction of urinary nitrates Normal: Negative Associations: Urinary tract infection (UTI) from a nitrate reductase-positive bacteria (E. coli, Proteus, Enterobacter, Klebsiella, Streptococcus faecalis and Staphylococcus aureus). Option: A. coli: it is nitrate reductase positive bacteria leading to nitrite test positive. It is the most common cause of UTI. Option: B. Proteus: it is nitrate reductase positive bacteria leading to nitrite test positive. Option: C. Enterobacter: it is nitrate reductase positive bacteria leading to nitrite test positive.

questions.text: A 60-years-old male underwent a urine examination and was positive for leukocyte esterase. What are the underlying conditions responsible for it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Leukocyte Esterase An enzyme present in certain WBCs (except lymphocytes ) Normal: Negative Associations: Inflammation of the urinary tract, sterile pyuria (balanitis, urethritis, tuberculosis, bladder tumors, nephrolithiasis, foreign bodies, exercise, glomerulonephritis, corticosteroids, and cyclophosphamide), fever, glomerulonephritis, pelvic inflammation Option: A. tuberculosis : this condition leads to inflammation which causes positive leukocyte esterase test positive. Tuberculosis can be associated with sterile pyuria. Option: B . bladder tumors : this condition leads to inflammation which causes positive leukocyte esterase test positive. Option: C. nephrolithiasis: this condition leads to inflammation which causes positive leukocyte esterase test positive.

questions.text: A 55-years-old male with tenderness and swelling at the great toe. His urine is examined and shows the following: Name the crystals present:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uric acid CRYSTALS: They are translucent crystals End products of metabolism are found highly concentrated in the urine and can precipitate in the form of crystals. several types of crystals are associated with certain diseases. For example, cholesterol crystals are seen in polycystic renal disease and nephrotic syndrome polycystic renal disease; leucine and tyrosine crystals are associated with severe liver disease. Option: A. uric acid: Yellow to orange-brown, diamond- or barrel-shaped crystals Associations: Acid urine, hyperuricosuria, uric acid nephropathy, normal

:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. calcium oxalates: Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Associations: Ethylene glycol poisoning, acid urine, hyperoxaluria.It is not seen in the above image. Option: C. triple phosphate: "Coffin lid" appearance crystals Associations: Alkaline urine, decreased urine volume, UTI from urease-producing bacteria (Proteus, Klebsiella) It is not seen in the above case.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. calcium oxalates: Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Associations: Ethylene glycol poisoning, acid urine, hyperoxaluria.It is not seen in the above image. Option: C. triple phosphate: "Coffin lid" appearance crystals Associations: Alkaline urine, decreased urine volume, UTI from urease-producing bacteria (Proteus, Klebsiella) It is not seen in the above case.

Extraedge:

Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones:- Struvite/Staghorn stones - Radiopaque, seen in alkaline urine, Rectangular/coffin lid appearance urinary stones, associated with urea-splitting organisms(.Ein th image-triple phosphate) Cystine stones - Radiopaque, seen in acidic urine, Hexagonal shaped, Very hard stones(G in the image) Uric acid crystals - Radiolucent, seen in acidic urine, seen in varying shapes(rhomboids or parallelograms)(Ain the picture) Calcium oxalate mono/dihydrate stones - Radiopaque, seen in acidic urine, Dumbbell shaped/envelope shaped, Most common type of renal calculi.(B in the image) Amoxycillin crystal ( I in image )resembling a branch of broom brush calcium phosphate crystal (D in image)star like brushite. Correct identification of urine crystals requires knowledge of crystal morphology, Urine pH, and appearance under polarizing light. Medications Associated with Nephrolithiasis and Nephrocalcinosis Calcium Stone Formation Loop diuretics Vitamin D Corticosteroids Calcium supplements Antacids (calcium and noncalcium antacids) Theophylline Acetazolamide* Amphotericin* Topiramate Uric Acid Stone Formation Salicylates Probenecid Allopurinol (usually associated with xanthine stones) Melamine (in contaminated infant formula and milk products) Medications that May Precipitate into Stones Triamterene Acyclovir (if infused rapidly intravenously) Indinavir Nelfinavir

questions.text: A 60 yrs male came to the casualty suffering from a urinary tract infection. On urine examination, it shows: Name the crystals present:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triple phosphate They are stag horn-shaped crystals Option C. triple phosphate: " Coffin lid " appearance crystals Associations : Alkaline urine , decreased urine volume, UTI from urease-producing bacteria ( Proteus, Klebsiella ). It is present in the above case.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. calcium oxalates : Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Option: A. uric acid : Yellow to orange-brown, diamond- or barrel-shaped crystals Associations : Acid urine, hyperuricosuria, uric acid nephropathy. These features are absent in the above case. Option: B. calcium oxalates Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Associations: Ethylene glycol poisoning, acid urine, hyperoxaluria. These features are absent in the above case.

questions.text: A 68 yrs female known case of diabetes is complaining of pain in their abdomen and fever. Her urine culture shows the presence of proteus bacilli, and her urine for crystal examination shows the following: Name the crystals present:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triple phosphate They are staghorn shaped crystal Triple phosphate : "Coffin lid " appearance crystals Associations : Alkaline urine , decreased urine volume, UTI from urease-producing bacteria (Proteus, Klebsiella). It is present in the above case.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. calcium oxalates : Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Option: A . uric acid : Yellow to orange-brown, diamond- or barrel-shaped crystals Associations : Acid urine, hyperuricosuria , uric acid nephropathy. These features are absent in the above case. Option: B . calcium oxalates Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Associations: Ethylene glycol poisoning, acid urine, hyperoxaluria. These features are absent in the above case.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male came to the casualty with complaint of pain in the joints with swelling and tenderness. On lab investigation, he had an increased level of uric acid with raised creatinine. Her urine for crystal study shows the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uric acid They are translucent crystals Option A. uric acid: Yellow to orange-brown, diamond- or barrel-shaped crystals Associations: Acid urine, hyperuricosuria, uric acid nephropathy, normal

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. calcium oxalates: Most commonly encountered crystal in human urine Refractile square "envelope" shape Associations: Ethylene glycol poisoning, acid urine, hyperoxaluria. It is not seen in the above image. Option: C. triple phosphate: "Coffin lid" appearance crystals Associations: Alkaline urine, decreased urine volume, UTI from urease-producing bacteria (Proteus, Klebsiella) It is not seen in the above case.

questions.text: A young patient presents with sudden onset of unilateral flank pain. The intensity of the pain can increase rapidly, and there are no alleviating factors. This pain, which is accompanied often by nausea and with following urine sediment findings, what is your diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystine stone Nephrolithiasis is a systemic disorder with calculi anywhere in the urinary system. Two common presentations: Renal colic and painless gross hematuria. The absence of hematuria does not exclude a stone (particularly when urine flow is completely obstructed by a stone) Sudden onset of unilateral flank pain → Stone moving into the ureter Examination of the urine sediment will usually reveal red and white blood cells and occasionally crystals. Crystals help in identifying the composition of the stone. Cystine crystals → Hexagonal (As seen in the image in the Q) Triple phosphate stones → Coffin lid appearance Calcium oxalate dihydrate stones → enveloped or bipyramidal s haped Uric acid stones are variable in size and shape → Barrels, rosettes, rhomboids , needles or hexagonal shaped

Highyeild:

Gold standard diagnostic test → Helical CT without contrast Helical CT detects stones as small as 1 mm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, Option C , Option D are as follows

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to emergency with c/o flank pain radiating to the groin and hematuria associated with the following urine sediment finding. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium oxalate dihydrate stones Two common presentations: Renal colic and painless gross hematuria. Sudden onset of unilateral flank pain → stone moving into the ureter Examination of the urine sediment will usually reveal red and white blood cells and occasionally crystals. Crystals help in identifying the composition of the stone. Calcium oxalate dihydrate stones → enveloped or bipyramidal shaped (As seen in the image in the Q)

Highyeild:

Crystalluria is a strong risk factor for new stone formation.
